title: ag.algebraic geometry - Determining the irreducible invariant subspaces of a permutation action by computing eigenspaces of a matrix
body: Let $\Sigma\subseteq\mathrm{Sym}(n)$ be a permutation group on $N:=\{1,...,n\}$ . My goal is to determine the irreducible invariant subspaces of the permutation action of $\Sigma$ on $\Bbb R^n$ , and I wonder whether the following technique always works. Consider the element-wise action of $\Sigma$ on the subsets $\{i,j\}\subseteq N$ for $i,j\in N$ . Let $o(i,j)$ denote the orbit of $\{i,j\}$ w.r.t. this action, and let $\mathcal O(\Sigma)$ denote the set of all these orbits. Now let $R:= \Bbb R[\,x_o\!\mid\! o\in\mathcal O(\Sigma)\,]$ be the polynomial ring over $\Bbb R$ with one variable $x_o$ for each orbit, and consider the matrix $M\in R^{n\times n}$ with components $ M_{ij} = x_{o(i,j)}$ . Question : Is is true that that the eigenspaces of this matrix $M$ are exactly the irreducible invariant subspaces of the permutation action of $\Sigma$ on $\Bbb R^n$ ? The matrix is symmetric, and thus the eigenspaces are real and mutually orthogonal. Each eigenspace is indeed $\Sigma$ -invariant, but is it also irreducible? I have applied this idea computationally and it never failed me. In practice, I do not use variables $x_o$ , but some algebraically independent number (or just some random numbers). But does it work always? ag.algebraic-geometry gr.group-theory rt.representation-theory group-actions invariant-theory Share Cite Improve this question Follow asked Jul 1, 2020 at 16:07 M. Winter 14.7k 3 3 gold badges 31 31 silver badges 83 83 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 2 2 $\begingroup$ The orbits of $G$ on pairs $\{x,y\}$ of points in the domain are called orbitals. The matrices associated with the orbitals span the centralizer algebra. The matrix $M$ in your question is somehow a generic element of the centraliser algebra. Thinking about the permutation representation with respect to a basis in which it is a direct sum of irreducible representations, you can work out an explicit description of the centraliser algebra - the books of Wielandt or Cameron, both called "Permutation groups", should have details. $\endgroup$ Padraig Ó Catháin –  Padraig Ó Catháin 2020-07-01 16:44:29 +00:00 Commented Jul 1, 2020 at 16:44 $\begingroup$ If the answer to your precise question is not 'yes' then some minor modification should be true, though note the orbital matrices are not always symmetric. $\endgroup$ Padraig Ó Catháin –  Padraig Ó Catháin 2020-07-01 16:46:52 +00:00 Commented Jul 1, 2020 at 16:46 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
